Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Rocky Mountains-Great Plains Graduate Research Workshops in Combinatorics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Rocky Mountain-Great Plains Graduate Research Workshop in Combinatorics (GRWC), will be held in Laramie, WY (2016), Denver, CO (2017) and Ames, IA (2018), building upon successful NSF-funded workshops in 2014 and 2015. Each workshop will involve approximately 39 graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, and 10 or more faculty members in an intense two-week collaborative research experience. Participants will work to solve important, relevant problems from graph theory, enumeration, combinatorial matrix theory, finite geometry, and other modern sub-disciplines of combinatorics. Students will prepare open problems prior to the workshop under the guidance of faculty mentors from the organizing committee, which consists of faculty from Iowa State University, the University of Colorado Denver, the University of Denver, the University of Nebraska Lincoln, and the University of Wyoming. These problems, presented at the workshop by their proposers or hosted on the workshop's secure problem wiki, will be worked on by small groups of participating students, postdocs, and faculty. For more information about the GRWC, including a detailed description of the workshop format, please see the workshop website at http://sites.google.com/site/rmgpgrwc

The goal of the collaborations at the heart of the GRWC is to produce high-quality, publishable research on a variety of topics. Another longer-term goal of the workshop is to help student participants expand their professional research networks. A strong research network is often a crucial part of building a generative and sustainable research program, and establishing these connections at an early career stage can have a long-term positive effect on the quality, impact, and depth of a professional's research portfolio. Participation in the GRWC will allow students to cultivate a large professional network of peers from the combinatorics community with whom they will be able to interact and collaborate throughout their careers. The GRWC will also offer professional development workshops to help students and postdocs prepare for job searches and future careers in academia, industry, or government.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Rocky Mountain-Great Plains Graduate Research Workshop in Combinatorics (GRWC) held three workshops supported by this grant: GRWC 2016 was held July 17 - July 29, 2016 at the University of Wyoming in Laramie, WY. GRWC 2017 was held July 9 - July 22, 2017 at CU Denver and the University of Denver in Denver, CO. GRWC 2018 was held from May 20 - June 2, 2018 at Iowa State University, in Ames, Iowa.   These were the third, fourth, and fifth in a series of annual summer workshops and continuation activities that began in 2014.

GRWC uses student-posed problems, which are presented during the first week.  Faculty mentors help students cultivate good problems and develop brief written descriptions as part of the pre-workshop professional development.  The research in GRWC is done in collaborative research groups, which are formed in the first week and do much of their work in the second. During the second week, in addition to research, various professional development group activities also take place.  Research on the problems continues after the workshop, with some groups holding small additional research gatherings, in order to complete the project.

Participants reported a very positive experience (100% would recommend GRWC to others). Participant comments from the 2018 GRWC include:

"I loved the collaborative environment. I didn't have any experience doing research outside of my dissertation project before this workshop, and it opened up my eyes to the different ways that research can happen."

"GRWC (and the pre-workshop at IMA) emphasized to me that there are many different ways to 'succeed,' with jobs in industry and jobs in academia with varying levels of research/teaching responsibilities. I'm more confident than I was before that I'll be able to find some job which would make me happy."

GRWC is aimed at graduate students and postdoctoral associates in combinatorics and related fields.  GRWC was conceived in part as a response to emerging challenges and modern career realities for mathematics PhDs.   The increasing complexity and interdisciplinary nature of important problems in mathematics and its applications now frequently requires collaboration of researchers with different backgrounds.  Due to the explosive growth of new opportunities in industry and government, the academic job market's stagnant growth, and increasing interest among students in nonacademic opportunities, more new mathematics PhDs are taking nonacademic positions.  In addition, an increasingly diverse group of institutions, including small liberal arts schools, are expecting their faculty members to maintain active research programs. Limited time and lack of local collaborators present challenges to these faculty.  Experience in research teams and a strong network of collaborators can help such faculty maintain their research programs.   GRWC helps address these needs for more significant exposure to collaborative research environments, opportunities to build collaboration networks, and better professional development activities focused on industrial and government opportunities as part of graduate student training.
